clean_content:
Definition / general

* Rare enlargement of regional lymph nodes caused by the presence of silicone carried from tributary organs* Either an incidental finding or causes painful / enlarged lymph node* May be associated with granulomatous inflammation ([Histol Histopathol 1997;12:1003](9302562))

Terminology

* Silicone lymphadenopathy

Sites

* Draining lymph nodes of the implant site, commonly axillary lymph nodes ([Respiratory Medicine CME 2011;4:126](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1755001711000029))

Pathophysiology

* Silicone is widely used in implants, especially augmentation mammoplasty and joint prostheses ([Hum Pathol 1980;11:240](6995270))* Once released into tissue, silicone migrates to distant sites through lymphatic channels and bloodstream* Once it reaches lymph nodes, it elicits a reaction and cause silicone lymphadenopathy

Etiology

* Rupture / leak of the implant, or implant 'bleeds', or releases microparticles into blood / lymphatics

Clinical features

* Enlarged lymph nodes* Asymptomatic or with pain

Diagnosis

* Biopsy

Radiology description

* Ultrasonogram: hyperechoeic (increased echogenicity of the lymph node mediastinum with dirty acoustic shadowing), beginning in the hilum and progressing outward through the cortex with time and amount of silicone* In severe cases, snowstorm appearance

Prognostic factors

* Depends upon the amount of silicone and severity of the reaction

Case reports

* 35 year old woman with axillary silicone lymphadenopathy ([J Med Case Rep 2009;3:6442](19830102))* 40 year old woman with silicone lymphadenopathy involving intramammary lymph nodes ([AJR Am J Roentgenol 1994;162:1089](8165987))* 45 year old woman with axillary silicone lymphadenopathy secondary to augmentation mammaplasty ([Indian J Plast Surg 2010;43:206](21217983))* 47 year old woman with silicone lymphadenopathy mimicking lymphoma ([J Clin Pathol 2000;53:549](10961180))* 49 year old woman with lymphadenopathy associated with total joint prostheses ([J Bone Joint Surg Am 1996;78:588](8609139))* 59 year old woman with silicone migration to the contralateral axillary lymph nodes and breast after highly cohesive silicone gel implant failure ([Cases J 2009;2:6420](20101283))* 71 year old woman with siliconoma in internal mammary lymph node ([Radiology Case Reports 2011;6(4)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1930043315302120))

Treatment

* Removal of lymph nodes

Clinical images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodessiliconeimplantthumbimg01.jpg)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3010785/figure/F0003/)

Rupture of implant

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodessiliconeimplant_sciencedirect01.jpg)](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1755001711000029#fig1)
 
[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodessiliconeimplant_sciencedirect02.jpg)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1930043315302120#fig1)
 
[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodessiliconeimplant_sciencedirect03.jpg)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1930043315302120#fig2)

Various images

Gross description

* No specific gross features* Enlarged and firmer than normal* Extreme cases show distorted architecture and fibrosis

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Diffuse follicular hyperplasia* Histiocytes with vacuolated cytoplasm especially inside the sinusoids* Histiocytes cause foreign body granulomatous reaction, giant cells and empty vacuoles* Giant cells have refractile and non-birefringent particles* Asteroid bodies may be seen* Silicone from orthopedic devices: prominent granulomatous reaction with clumps of granular yellowish refractile material* Silicone from mammary prostheses: finer vacuolated deposits

Microscopic (histologic) images

Contributed by Dr. Mark R. Wick  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/wick/silicone%20deposits%20lymph%20node%20axillary%20micro.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/wick/silicone%20deposits%20lymph%20node%20axillary%20micro.jpg)

Silicone in axillary lymph node

Subcapsular sinus diffusely expanded

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodessiliconeimplantthumbimg05.jpg)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2726483/figure/F5/)

Vacuoles which contain refractile material

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodessiliconeimplant_sciencedirect06.jpg)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1930043315302120#fig4)

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodessiliconeimplantthumbimg06.jpg)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1731232/figure/F1/)

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodessiliconeimplantthumbimg07.jpg)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC500799/figure/F2/)

Silicone leakage

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodessiliconeimplantthumbimg08.jpg)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC500799/figure/F4/)

Silicone particles in cystic spaces

Cytology description

* Numerous multi-vacuolated histiocytic cells both scattered individually as well as in aggregates* Contain clear, refractile but non-polarizable material* Background may show scattered lymphocytes

Positive stains

* Histiocytes: [CD68](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd68.html) and [CD44](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd44.html)

Negative stains

* Silicone is negative for [PAS](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainspas.html), [mucin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmucins.html), [trichrome](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainstrichrome.html), [oil red O](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsoilredo.html)

Electron microscopy description

* Electron opaque fragmented spicules or flakes

Differential diagnosis

* [Fat necrosis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/breastfatnecrosis.html)* **Lipogranuloma*** [Metastatic lobular carcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesmetastases.html#breastadenocarcinoma)* **Metastatic renal cell carcinoma*** **Metastatic signet ring cell carcinoma*** **Signet ring cell type lymphoma*** [Sinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodessinushistiocytosiswithmassivelymph.html)

Additional references

* [Ioachim's Lymph Node Pathology, 4th Edition, 2008](http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/B00E294BLO/pathologyoutl-20), [Stavros: Breast Ultrasound, 1st Edition, 2004](http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/039751624X/pathologyoutl-20), [Am J Surg Pathol 2005;29:506](15767806)
